title: Bok fans at sixes and twos over tactics
text:
Sport Bok fans at sixes and twos over tactics

Semifinal will see Boks try to wear out Wales, and Jérôme Garcès throws a spanner in the works

If there are two words driving South African rugby fans to distraction – even more than the mere mention of French referee Jérôme Garcès’ name – they are the six-two split.

Ever since Springbok coach Rassie Erasmus decided to go into overkill mode by naming a forwards-heavy bench (six to two backline players) for the Rugby World Cup pool game against Italy, Bok fans have found their allegiances put in a Catch 22.

Erasmus’ plan – which is basically to create opportunities by suffocating the opposition through the use of two tight fives and a defence designed to chase ball-carriers as if they are making off with wallets and cellphones – has worked a treat in the games in which it was used.

The Italians were dispatched 49-3 and Japan were emasculated 26-3, but the Bok supporters were not enamoured of the style – or the lack thereof – in which it was done.

So when Erasmus this week named another squad of 23 with a six-two split on the bench for today’s semifinal against Wales (11am kick-off), there was a collective throwing up of the hands in anticipation of another dour struggle in which the Boks would play the long forwards game to wear down the Six Nations champions in the final quarter.

The main reason South African supporters are finding Erasmus’ tactics difficult to understand is because they are counterintuitive.

Fourteen forwards in a match-day squad suggest no tries, yet going into the semifinals, the Boks were the leading try scorers in the competition with 30 to New Zealand’s 29.

Granted, the cancellation of their final pool game against an Italian team that leaked almost 50 points to the Boks is the only reason Steve Hansen’s team have scored fewer tries than Erasmus’ men, but had they played that match, the South Africans would still be the second-highest try scorers in the competition.

The Bok attack is back to front, or – given their method – front to back.

They ratchet up pressure by not allowing the opposition pack to breathe, use their ridiculous line-speed in defence to catch said opponents in no-man’s land and force them into a mistake they can punish either via kicking for poles or a rolling maul that clocked 45m in one gallop against Japan.

The often maligned kicking game is a different take on territorial play. Most teams try to regain the kick directly.

While retaining the kick would be first prize, a close second prize is catching the opponents in the wrong place and putting them under pressure, which often leads to a line-out for the best line-out in the competition (57 out of 57) in their own half.

Against Wales, the Boks will run into sterner forwards than Japan, a team whose kicking game picked apart their rush defence last year because they have good kickers and chasers, and a defence forged in the image of defence coach Shaun Edwards, who looks an awful lot like the guy in charge of enforcing the no-touching rule at strip joints.

If there is a weakness in the Welsh team, it is the absence of injured number eight Josh Navidi, who was a pain in the backside at the break down in November last year and fullback Liam Williams’ withdrawal with an ankle injury.

Then there is the return of outside centre Jonathan Davies, who combines iron fist with velvet glove so seamlessly and is world class, but his return looks rushed, while Williams’ replacement, the experienced Leigh Halfpenny, is less explosive than the man he is replacing in attack.

Of course, the Boks are without their player of the tournament, winger Cheslin Kolbe, who will be replaced S’bu Nkosi.

Psychologically, the Welsh hold the cards after winning all four of the fixtures since the 2015 Rugby World Cup quarterfinal.

As for the other two words driving Bok fans to distraction – Jérôme Garcès is a former helicopter builder who is so hands-free he may well be a helicopter referee. He should turn the match into a lottery.
description: Semifinal will see Boks try to wear out Wales, and Jérôme Garcès throws a spanner in the works.
